headline: Old Fashioned Peach Cobbler
description: This old-fashioned peach cobbler recipe features flaky, homemade pastry filled with fresh peaches tossed in citrus juice with nutmeg and cinnamon.

video.description: Nutmeg and cinnamon flavor fresh peaches wrapped in flaky pastry.
video.name: Old Fashioned Peach Cobbler

name: Old Fashioned Peach Cobbler
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds fresh peaches - peeled, pitted, and sliced

recipeInstructions.text: Make crust: Sift together flour, 3 tablespoons sugar, and salt in a medium bowl. Work in shortening with a pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Whisk together egg and cold water in a small bowl. Sprinkle over flour mixture; work with hands to form dough into a ball. Wrap with plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Roll out 1/2 of the chilled dough to 1/8-inch thickness. Place in a 9x13-inch baking dish, covering the bottom and halfway up the sides.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 20 minutes.

Make filling: Mix peaches, orange juice, and lemon juice in a large saucepan. Add butter and cook over medium-low heat until butter is melted. Stir together sugar, cornstarch, cinnamon, and nutmeg in a bowl; mix into peach mixture until combined. Pour into baked crust.
Roll remaining dough to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut into 1/2-inch-wide strips. Weave strips into a lattice over peaches. Sprinkle with 1 tablespoon sugar, then drizzle with melted butter.
Bake in the preheated oven until top crust is golden brown, 35 to 40 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This was easy especially if you buy the premade crust - the only thing left to do is just the filling and it's done. It tasted so good. :)
It was awesome. Every one who got loved it!!!!!

Don't like peach pie, said I wouldn't eat it. I made the recipe ðŸ˜‹ and I'm a Believer. Just one tweak. I use one cup of white sugar and 1 cup of brown. I fed it to everyone that would try my first attempt. They've already asked me to make it for Thanksgiving.
I did not add the orange juiceâ€¦it smells and looks delicious!

The crust is a little bit of work but worth it, I will use this crust again for other recipes. I have made this several times and everytime I make it for parties people ask for the recipe. There is never leftovers! The only change I made was increasing the cornstarch to 2T. This is a good old fashioned cobbler like my grandmother from KY used to make.

Couple of changes, like omitted the nutmeg because I donâ€™t like it. Also omitted the thickening for the peaches because I prefer a juicy filling. Also used mango juice instead of orange juice. I like the homemade crust because thatâ€™s what my mother did. Brings back memories of her.
great but should increase dough recipe. wasnt enough!
Everybody enjoyed it.

I love the recipe!!! I really use it for the crust and I don't use the orange juice. I also add more cinnamon, nutmeg I also add a touch of allspice. The crust is absolutely the best!! I add cinnamon to the dusting you put on top. Today will be my first time adding the melted butter to the top, I've made this several times never noticed that part
It is easy to make I have in the oven now. I love this recipe. I am also a PSW. Hoping my client enjoys this tomorrow.
I liked the recipe; however, next time I would reduce the sugar by one-half. I like that it has lemon and orange juices in the recipe.

The cobbler is in the oven baking. This was not an easy recipe for sure. It's time consuming. I didn't have lemon or orange juice so I used what I had on hand, Body Armor Orange Mango (the flavor of the sauce was good). Also after reading some reviews I used a slotted spoon and laid the peaches in the baked crust then added some liquid. I'll update my review after tasting the finished cobbler.
I love this recipe simple and easy
The recipe was great never made a cobbler before. And I love peach cobbler.
Easy and so good!!!

Tasted very good. I used more than half the dough for the bottom layer so I didn't have as much for the lattice crust on top. Aesthetically, that could have been better. Also, this tasted even better more than a day after I made it. I would make it again for sure.
The only change I made was that I didn't have any orange juice, but, I did have some peach juice cocktail, so replaced the orange juice with that.

Made exactly as written.... Everyone loved it!
Thanks for a great recipe !
So easy and delicious! I halved the recipe and it was more than enough for my family. Baking the bottom crust made this cobbler disappear quickly!
I used all fresh peaches from a friendâ€™s tree. This recipe I would definitely recommend, it was delicious!
I made it! And, it was delicious!

I followed most of the reviews- 1 1/2 dough recipe, 15 peaches, I cut the sugar down to 3/4 c white sugar/ 1/2 c brown sugar, 1/4c lemon juice, 1 cup orangeade (out of juice, dont judge :-) ), 3.5 T cornstarch, 1.5 tsp cinnamon, 1/8 tsp nutmeg. it came out great- a little issue with the pie sides slouching, but it all tasted good.
My lattice work needs some work, but this was the bomb at work today!!!!! Happy 4h everyone

I followed Twitcherys lead and made the filling per instructions. This is an excellent pie filling as well as for a cobbler. I even think the filling would be excellent as a sauce for ice cream, waffles, or pancakes. Will be making this again.
Just like the Ladies at church make
This is a true homemade dessert and you can tell in your first bite! It brings out the nostalgia. I paired it with French vanilla ice cream, but whipped cream would be just as good!
Followed suggestion of other reviewer. 3/4 cup of each sugar, 3 T corn starch. 1/3 c. Lemon juice, 1/3 cup orange juice, 2 T vanilla. No nutmeg or cinnamon.
Idk about this as it's in the oven now. I will update, if possible, later once I have feedback from my eaters. I, myself, don't eat this, but my kids' dad does and other friends do.

Yes I used Pillsbury pie crust instead of making it from scratch. I was pressed for time. And I used glitter crystLs on top instead of white sugar. It looks delicious. I made it for my Christmas dinner dessert.
It was wonderful tastes so good and really good with homemade whipped cream

I only changed one thing-Orange Juice. Replaced with water.
Absolutely delicious.

Reduced for two and added apples and raisins and a splash of brandy. As well as making it according to the recipe and it was remarkably excellent. I make this for holidays the full recipe and reduced and either way it's always gone the next day!

So yummy! Thanks to all who reviewed and recommended to increase the crust recipe (I made 1-1/2x) and the volume of peaches (I used 4 lbs). In addition, I added about 3/4 blueberries and dusted the top with pecan pieces before baking. It was delicious!
Tbh, I thought this was just ok. I did double the crust and cut back the sugar and citrus juices which worked well. I donâ€™t think the single batch would have been enough.
This was awesome! My entire family absolutely loved it!

I made this with fresh free-stone peaches from GA. I wanted it to taste like my Nanaâ€™s (miss her) and it turned out amazing. I stuck to the recipe exactly, though I had to let the peach filling mixture sit overnight to allow time to make dough, bake first layer, etc. I reheated and then added sugar and corn starch so the binder would be fresh. It was perfect!! I wouldnâ€™t change a thing. I shared with my friends and family and we all loved it!!!

I cheated and used Pilsbury pie crusts. Since I've never made a pie before in my life, I thought I'd take one step at a time. I made this for my husband who is really picky. Anytime he tells me "my Grandma made ______; and it was so good" I know I'm in for a challenge. When he tasted this cobbler, he pronounced it good!
Too much sugar. Being a diabetic, I used less sugar, and used 2Tbs of cornstarch, in place of the flour. Next time, Iâ€™m using Splenda instead. It was very good, otherwise..
Excellent cobbler!!! Thank you for sharing!
Read reviews and decreased sugar to 1/2 c brown and 1/2 c white and it was plenty sweet. The crust is really good and wasnâ€™t soggy. I also used 3 Tbsp of cornstarch and that made.
Never made or tasted cobbler before. Easy recipe to follow. Way to sweet for my liking. Seemed very runny. I did receive favorable compliments.
Delicious!!! I mixed everything as is and let the cobbler sit overnight. Are the next day and....DELICIOUS!
Scrumptiously delicious ... the perfect "old fashioned" recipe for peach cobbler
One of the best peach cobblers I've had the privilege to eat! And I've eaten alot of peach cobbler! It's also the first time I've ever made one! So I had fun all smiles!

My husband liked it but I found it too sweet even with less sugar than the recipe called for. The recipe also doesn't say how many cups of peaches, (just pounds) or whether they are to be weighed before or after the pits have been taken out. I also failed to make the dough as described. Even after placing in the fridge it wouldn't hang together for the bottom or for cutting the top crust.
This is the best tasting peach cobbler I've ever made!!
Excellent!
Absolutely out of this world! I used the updated recipe, and only did the top crust. After I took it out of the oven, I realized I forgot to add the vanilla, but it honestly wasnâ€™t needed.

Take the advice of the people with the most helpful positive reviews. I was in a hurry and missed this and ended up with a soupy mess. The edits others have may could have resolved the major issues of 1) being soooo watery (i literally siphoned off 12-16 oz of liquid at the end) 2) a bit too sweet (and I like sweet generally so that is saying a lot). Follow those comments and this will probably come out really good.

This is a very soft crust but very flaky. The filling is great. I will say that I could find frozen peaches during the Corona virus Pandemic , so I used canned peaches that I drained and rinsed well. My dad who LOVES peach cobbler could not tell they were canned. He is very picky and loves this recipe. I did not change anything but I used large
flake sanding sugar on top for a little extra crunch. This will be a keeper for sure.
Used 1/4 tsp pure vanilla and frozen peach slices. The flavor was off-the-chain!

I wouldn't change much- double the crust, and cook the fruit to get it to the right thickness before making the cobbler. My mama always made extra dough so she could bake several narrow strips while the bottom crust baked. Then as she was adding the filling she would lay those strips throughout the cobbler. Mama made the best and this is as close as I have found. Oh my!!! Hers was a little bit of Heaven in a 9 X 13 baking dish!!!
Only added 1 teaspoon vanilla. Will definitely make again.

This makes the Best peach cobbler I've ever had! The only thing I add is a pinch of ground ginger to the simmering peaches.
The dough is so easy to work with, that I actually look forward to preparing it! Yummy!

Made all the recommended changes, except used 1/2 shortening and 1 c butter in the crust when doing 1.5 x the recipe. I would also reduce the amount of sugar in the crust. The filling is sweet enough!
the crust came out so nice on this cobbler. Family said add to favorites

I made this one for our xmas office luncheon. Was a big hit and I got asked for the recipe. Had to double the ingredients cause there were 30 people to serve. Now I'm going too have to make it for our family xmas dinner.
Great Recipe
I love this recipe, I made this peach cobbler a few times. Thank you so much for sharing now it's my family recipe. Much love enjoy.
Added vanilla 1 tsp and decreased the sugar to 1 3/4 cup. Came out perfect
Awesome recipe!!!

This is the best peach cobbler recipe Iâ€™ve ever used. I always get rave reviews when I serve it. I must be doing something wrong when I make the crust though. It tends to tear apart when I roll it out and put it in the pan. I always have to piece it together. What am I doing wrong? The crust has wonderful flavor.
No changes and already made another batch! Very yummy but I have trouble keeping the crust together. it may be because I live in such a dry environment. Definitely keeping and sharing this one.
Too much liquid goes in the filling, the crust did not taste good, it was like peach jam in a funny tasting crust. I will stick with my old Betty Crocker circa 1950â€™s peach pie recipe.

Iâ€™ve Got to give myself 5 Stars because this cobbler is absolutely delicious! I did substitute half of the white sugar with brown sugar; personal choice. .. and added a dash of vanilla flavoring... Delish!!
This the best peach cobbler I have ever eaten. The crust is so good.I think I will use it for my other pies!
Loved it!!! I added a little extra corn starch. Next time I will use less sugar. But there will definitely be a next time

Too much liquid in this recipe which makes it too soupy for our taste. I cut the sugar in half because I thought 2 cups of sugar would be too sweet. The flavor of the sauce was very good. I made it a second time, cut the liquids in half and added 12 oz of fresh raspberries. Much better!

I have made this cobbler about 20 times or so...with and without homemade crust, also in my conventional oven and my Ninja Foodi Grill Air Fryer and every time, its a hit!! I have made it using more juice because the original peach cobbler tends to have nice slightly thick juice which complements the crust and I have made it dry...I prefer it with the thick juice..I also top it off with Sugar in the Raw to give it a nice crispy crystalized look.

Delicious! I followed the most helpful reviews suggestions, minus the vanilla (I thought I had some, but no.). My cobbler was still a bit runny. I used a little over 4 lb of peaches, not very ripe ones, firm. I did feel that maybe I needed a bit more crust, but it worked out well. Next time Iâ€™ll make some changes, more crust, more cornstarch perhaps?
Delicious! My family loved it! The only change I made was I added a teaspoon of vanilla to the peaches:)

I added a little peach schnapps. All the friends
that were here loved it.
Excellent

Had a pound of frozen peaches I wanted to use up, so I just adjusted the ingredients for the peaches. I did do the full crust recipe however, and found it just right amount for a full bottom & top crust (no lattice for me) in 8x8 pan. Came out beautifully.
Delicious! I love this recipe, it's very simple and quick to whip up. A crowd pleaser for sure! Thank you for sharing.
I made this dessert looking for a recipe close to my grandmother's who was from Louisiana. This recipe was right on! If I closed my eyes and ate some I would swear my grandmomma made it.

I've made this several times. I love it, I add mango to the peaches. Became diabetic last year and thought I would try with Trivia. It had a bitter after taste. So disappointing. I realize it would not be sugar free, but lower sugar.
Delicious! But it was runny. Gave it five stars anyway assuming it was my error.
this looks great, just like my gmas. but.... I was wondering if anyone has used frozen berries in place of the peaches & if it would be the same recipe to follow
Way too much liquid that will not easily thicken. Cut down orange juice to half a cup or even one quarter. Also, pastry needs butter as well as shortening for flavor.

Not a great recipe, and this isnâ€™t cobbler, its pie.
As written, it doesnâ€™t have enough cornstarch to set it up (depends how juicy your peaches are though), is far too sweet and the crust needs more instruction wrt adding liquid... if youâ€™re at different altitudes it can come out all wrong.
I still say itâ€™s not a cobbler at all... but for those who had it work for them, bon appetit!

I use my Mother's pie crust recipe for this which none can compare to. Follow Twitchers suggestions for tweaking the recipe. It is loaded with lots of flavor. If I have them, I stir in fresh blueberries with the filling.

This is DELICIOUS!! I used a Pil****ry pie crust (1.5 of them) on the bottom, and the other 1/2 on the top, and then followed TWITCHERY's recipe, which was just the right amount of liquid and sugar (which is much less than the original recipe). I know... if you aren't going to make it the way it's written, don't rate it. But... it was DELICIOUS!!
I made this following the recipe exactly. My husband, who has loved peach cobbler his entire life, said that this recipe is definitely a keeper. He LOVED it!
I was out of nutmeg so I used a bit more cinnamon instead and it was perfect. I loved how the top crust got crisp. Perfect cobbler every time!
Love this!! Itâ€™s a wonderful recipe. My family asks me to make all the time now!
Pretty good family loved it
Had a lb of frozen peaches, so everything in 1/2. Let you know. Also, I know this recipe of Elena is how I to remember it.

A lot of Southern peach cobbler recipes are soupy. My grandmother was from St Louis and she made the best cobbler I've ever eaten. Hers wasn't runny or soupy. I just don't have her recipe. I don't really care for cobblers with the biscuit topping. I was looking for a cobbler with crust and came across this recipe. 

This one has wonderful flavor with the combination of orange and lemon juice and the combination of spices. I added 3 tbsp of cornstarch( I prefer firmer cobblers). Thank you for a wonderfully flavored peach cobbler.
So delicious! Both the crust and the peach filling turned out greatI did remove 1 cup of sugar from the filling and it's still fantastic!
A little bit of work but very well worth it. I little too much lemon juice for my taste but other than that I will be baking this again, just cut back on.
Turned out amazing and so easy
I halved the sugar and my husband still said it was too sweet. But it sure tasted good to me!
super yummy!! The perfect blend of sweet and tart! Highly recommend! Everyone loved it !! Make it , you wont regret it. You will be the hit of your gathering!
I will definitely make it again

I was worried about making this becasue my wife had tried a different recipe and her crust did not come out well. This recipe is incredible. I made this for the first time. The only changes I made were that I used canned peaches and substituted syrup from the canned peaches instead of orange juice. Everyone at the cookout ate it up. Will definitely make it again.
Pretty good, but might leave the sugar out of the crust and double the cornstarch next time.

I'm an old man who is rather new at cooking, but I had the same experience with this cobbler that I do with lots of pies. It was delicious but much of the bottom crust stuck to the bottom of the dish and became very hard. Am I supposed to grease the dish? It wasn't called for in the recipe.
Good flavor although my dough turned out too soft to work into ribbons
